intro: Commiphora sarandensis subsp. sarandensis, commonly known as the Sarandian myrrh tree, is a small to medium-sized evergreen shrub or tree native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing plants. The plant is characterized by its smooth, grayish bark and small, elliptical leaves with a leathery texture. It produces a fragrant resin, often referred to as myrrh, which has been used traditionally for medicinal and aromatic purposes. The species is adapted to dry, hot climates and is often found in rocky or sandy soils.
